comments: plural

Possibly a derivation of PS *oarpēnē 'female cousin' (> Skolt vuäʹrben-) (Lehtiranta 2001: 94–95) ~ Finnish orpana and as such ultimately a loan from PII *Hárbha- 'small, weak, young' (Holopainen 2019: 168–170).

A derivative of puäʹres 'old' (< PS *poarēs 'old'), which itself has been thought to be a Indo-Iranian borrowing, cf. PII *parHa-s 'ferner; jenseitig; früher; später; fremd, feinlich' (Holopainen 2019: 189). Front vocalic Udm. pereś and Komi përïś are parallel borrowings (Pre-Permic *pärä-). Perhaps Skolt is a calque of Finnic vanhemmat 'parents' (lit. "olders").
As a kinship term a PS innovation
A diminutive derivative of päʹrnn 'son; child'
Cognate with Finnish ylkä 'young man; groom' (obsolete).
Reconstructed as *nejδe in UEW, but based on Permic (and Saami as well) the first-syllable vowel was clearly *ä.

A compound of maaddâr (unclear if this word exists as an independent lexeme in Skolt, cognate of North Sámi máttar 'forefather', Sami words are ultimately loans from PF *mandër 'continent, mainland', although the semantic relationship is peculiar) and puärraz 'parents'

A compound of maaddâr (unclear if this word exists as an independent lexeme in Skolt, cognate of North Sámi máttar 'forefather', Sami words are ultimately loans from PF *mandër 'continent, mainland', although the semantic relationship is peculia)r and ruåđ (plural of ruått 'relative', most likely a loan from Russian род)

forefather', a compound of maaddâr (unclear if this word exists as an independent lexeme in Skolt, cognate of North Sámi máttar 'forefather', Sami words are ultimately loans from PF *mandër 'continent, mainland', although the semantic relationship is peculiar) and eʹčč 'father'.
forefather, great grandfather', a compound of maaddâr (unclear if this word exists as an independent lexeme in Skolt, cognate of North Sámi máttar 'forefather') and äʹjj 'grandfather'
foremother, great grandmother', a compound of maaddâr (unclear if this word exists as an independent lexeme in Skolt, cognate of North Sámi máttar 'forefather') and äkk 'grandmother'

PS *ākkō 'grandmother' is a derivative of PS *ākkē 'old woman' that is in traditional sources thought to be a cognate with Finnic *akka 'old woman' (Lehtiranta 2001: 12–13; SSA: 64–65). The vowel correspondence is atypical of inherited vocabulary, PU *a-a yields PS *uo-ē. As such the underlying Sami word has to be Finnic borrowing (Aikio 2009: 244). Similar words denoting female relatives are common in world's languages.

Similar words denoting female relatives are common in world's languages.
A compound of jiẹʹnn (genitive of jeäʹnˈn 'mother') and jeäʹnˈn 'mother'. Possibly a calque of Finnish äidinäiti 'mother's mother'.
A derivative of  äʹjj 'grandfather', cf. North Sami áddjut 'grandchild'  < áddjá 'grandfather'

A compound of pääʹrn (genitive of päʹrnn 'child; son') and nijdd 'daughter'

A compound of niõđ (genitive of nijdd 'daughter') and nijdd 'daughter'

Comparison in UEW is irregular to the extent that it should probably be discarded, connection to IE words like Lith sesuo unclear (Kümmel 2013). The word can be used also of 'father's female cousin' (Pelto 1962: 68–69).
The word can be used of 'mother's male cousin' (Pelto 1962: 68–69).

Also 'mother's older female cousin' (Pelto 1962: 68–69).
Also 'mother's younger female cousin' (Pelto 1962: 68–69).

According to SSA Skolt kaav (and related Sami words) is a borrowing from Finnish kave 'created being; human; girl, maiden', which in turn has been thought to be a Germanic borrowing *skapi-z (OHG skaf) (LägLoS: 68–69). The Finnish kave is obsolete. The discrepancy in meaning between Finnish and Sami is striking.

The Sami word is thought to include an obscure derivational suffix. It is perhaps noteworthy that PU *ana/ëna 'mother-in-law' is not attested as such anywhere in Uralic, only in derivations like this Sami item or in the copulative compound *a/ëna-ëppə 'parents-in-law'.
Moshnikoff 2021 defines the word as 'brother's wife, paternal/maternal uncle's wife', according to Pelto 1962 the word is of older brother's wife.
According to Pelto 1962 vivv is also 'younger brother's wife'
older sister's husband', self-reciprocal pair with maakkâv
Sometimes also regarded as inherited from PU *wäŋəw, PS *vivvë, however, points to PU *wejwə/*wijwə. According to Moshnikoff 2021 'son-in-law', in Pelto 2021 also 'younger sister's/cousin's husband'
wife's older brother', a compound of vuõpp 'father-in-law' and bieʹll 'half'
wife's younger brother', a derivative of maakk 'older sister's husband' (reciprocal)
wife's older sister', a compound of vueʹn 'mother-in-law' and biẹʹll 'half'
